events.title: Founding of Rome
events.description: According to Roman legend, Romulus founds the city of Rome on the Palatine Hill.

events.title: Roman Republic Established
events.description: The Roman monarchy is overthrown and the Roman Republic is established, ending the rule of kings.

events.title: Sack of Rome by Gauls
events.description: The Gauls, led by Brennus, sack Rome, marking one of the city's greatest early defeats.

events.title: Appian Way Construction Begins
events.description: Construction begins on the Appian Way, the first major Roman road, connecting Rome to southern Italy and demonstrating Roman engineering prowess.

events.title: First Punic War Begins
events.description: Rome and Carthage begin the First Punic War over control of Sicily, marking Rome's expansion beyond Italy.

events.title: Hannibal Crosses the Alps
events.description: Carthaginian general Hannibal leads his army across the Alps to invade Italy during the Second Punic War.

events.title: Carthage Destroyed
events.description: Rome completely destroys Carthage at the end of the Third Punic War, eliminating its greatest rival.

events.title: Spartacus Revolt
events.description: Spartacus leads a major slave revolt against the Roman Republic, one of the largest slave uprisings in history, highlighting the extent and brutality of the Roman slave system.

events.title: Cicero Born
events.description: Marcus Tullius Cicero is born, later becoming Rome's greatest orator, philosopher, and statesman, whose writings preserve much of Roman political thought.

events.title: Virgil Born
events.description: Publius Vergilius Maro (Virgil) is born, later composing the Aeneid, Rome's national epic and one of the greatest works of Latin literature.

events.title: Cicero Assassinated
events.description: Cicero is assassinated on the orders of Mark Antony, ending the life of Rome's greatest orator and defender of the Republic.

events.title: Ovid Born
events.description: Publius Ovidius Naso (Ovid) is born, later becoming one of Rome's greatest poets, known for Metamorphoses and his influence on Western literature.

events.title: Death of Virgil
events.description: Virgil dies, leaving behind the Aeneid, which becomes the foundational epic of Roman literature and culture.

events.title: First Triumvirate
events.description: Julius Caesar, Pompey, and Crassus form a political alliance known as the First Triumvirate.

events.title: Caesar Crosses the Rubicon
events.description: Julius Caesar crosses the Rubicon River with his army, starting a civil war and defying the Senate.

events.title: Assassination of Julius Caesar
events.description: Julius Caesar is assassinated on the Ides of March by a group of senators led by Brutus and Cassius.

events.title: Battle of Actium
events.description: Octavian defeats Mark Antony and Cleopatra at the Battle of Actium, securing his position as sole ruler.

events.title: Augustus Becomes Emperor
events.description: Octavian is granted the title Augustus, marking the end of the Roman Republic and the beginning of the Roman Empire.

events.title: Aqua Virgo Aqueduct Completed
events.description: The Aqua Virgo aqueduct is completed, one of Rome's eleven major aqueducts that supplied the city with water, demonstrating advanced Roman engineering.

events.title: Death of Ovid
events.description: Ovid dies in exile, leaving behind a vast body of poetry including Metamorphoses, which becomes one of the most influential works of Western literature.

events.title: Great Fire of Rome
events.description: A devastating fire destroys much of Rome, and Emperor Nero is accused of starting it to clear land for his palace.

events.title: Eruption of Mount Vesuvius
events.description: Mount Vesuvius erupts, destroying the cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum and preserving them for posterity.

events.title: Year of the Four Emperors
events.description: Four different emperors rule Rome in a single year following Nero's death, causing civil war and instability that nearly destroys the empire.

events.title: Colosseum Completed
events.description: The Flavian Amphitheatre, known as the Colosseum, is completed and opened for gladiatorial games.

events.title: Nerva Adopts Trajan
events.description: Emperor Nerva adopts Trajan as his successor, beginning the era of the Five Good Emperors.

events.title: Roman Empire Reaches Maximum Extent
events.description: Under Trajan, the Roman Empire reaches its greatest territorial extent, stretching from Britain to Mesopotamia.

events.title: Death of Marcus Aurelius
events.description: Marcus Aurelius dies, ending the era of the Five Good Emperors and beginning a period of instability.

events.title: Crisis of the Third Century Begins
events.description: The assassination of Emperor Severus Alexander begins the Crisis of the Third Century, a period of military anarchy, economic collapse, and civil war that nearly destroys the Roman Empire.

events.title: Edict of Caracalla
events.description: Emperor Caracalla grants Roman citizenship to all free inhabitants of the empire.

events.title: Diocletian Becomes Emperor
events.description: Diocletian becomes emperor and institutes major reforms, including the division of the empire into East and West, ending the Crisis of the Third Century.

events.title: Edict of Milan
events.description: Emperors Constantine and Licinius issue the Edict of Milan, legalizing Christianity throughout the Roman Empire.

events.title: Constantinople Founded
events.description: Emperor Constantine establishes Constantinople as the new capital of the Roman Empire, shifting power to the East.

events.title: Christianity Becomes State Religion
events.description: Emperor Theodosius I makes Christianity the official state religion of the Roman Empire.

events.title: Final Division of the Empire
events.description: Upon the death of Theodosius I, the Roman Empire is permanently divided into Eastern and Western halves.

events.title: Sack of Rome by Visigoths
events.description: The Visigoths, led by Alaric, sack Rome, the first time the city has been captured in 800 years.

events.title: Sack of Rome by Vandals
events.description: The Vandals sack Rome, further weakening the Western Roman Empire.

events.title: Fall of Western Roman Empire
events.description: Romulus Augustulus, the last Western Roman Emperor, is deposed by Odoacer, marking the end of the Western Roman Empire.

events.title: Fall of Constantinople
events.description: The Ottoman Empire captures Constantinople, marking the end of the Eastern Roman (Byzantine) Empire.
